Name: Pietro Parolin
Role_Office: Secretary of State of His Holiness
Background: Cardinal Pietro Parolin, born in 1955 in Italy, is the Vatican Secretary of State and a leading figure in the Catholic Church's diplomacy. He was ordained in 1980 and entered the Holy See’s diplomatic service in 1986, serving in various countries and as Undersecretary for Relations with States. Known for his pragmatic, conciliatory approach, Parolin emphasizes dialogue, international cooperation, and peaceful resolution of conflicts. He supports Pope Francis's reforms and priorities, including social justice, care for migrants, and climate action, while upholding traditional Catholic teachings. Parolin is considered a skilled negotiator and a key architect of Vatican agreements with China and other countries.

Name: Fernando Filoni
Role_Office: Grand Master of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre
Background: Cardinal Fernando Filoni is an Italian prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1946, who has held several significant diplomatic and administrative roles within the Vatican. He served as Apostolic Nuncio to Iraq and Jordan during the Iraq War, demonstrating notable dedication to the local Christian community. Later, he became Prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples, overseeing global missionary activity. Known for his strong commitment to church diplomacy and missionary outreach, Filoni is regarded as a pragmatic and faithful defender of traditional Catholic teaching, while actively supporting dialogue with other religions and cultures, particularly in challenging contexts such as China and the Middle East.

Name: Luis Antonio Tagle
Role_Office: Pro-Prefect of the Dicastery for Evangelization
Background: Cardinal Luis Antonio Tagle is a Filipino prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, born in 1957 in Manila. He served as Archbishop of Manila from 2011 to 2019 before being appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples in the Vatican. Known for his humble lifestyle, strong pastoral presence, and deep theological insights, Tagle advocates for social justice, care for the poor, and a more compassionate, listening Church. He supports Pope Francis' vision of a Church that goes to the peripheries, emphasizing inclusivity and dialogue, particularly on issues affecting marginalized communities. His progressive approach and ability to communicate effectively with diverse audiences have made him a prominent figure in the global Catholic Church.

Name: Robert Francis Prevost OSA
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Bishops
Background: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost, OSA, is an American-born prelate of the Catholic Church and a member of the Order of Saint Augustine. Born in Chicago in 1955, he joined the Augustinians and was ordained a priest in 1982. Prevost has significant missionary experience in Peru and later served as Prior General of the Augustinian order from 2001 to 2013. In 2014, he was appointed Bishop of Chiclayo, Peru, and in 2023, Pope Francis named him Prefect of the Dicastery for Bishops, making him a key figure in episcopal appointments worldwide. Known for his emphasis on humility, discernment, and pastoral care, Prevost broadly aligns with Pope Francis’s vision for a more synodal, inclusive, and missionary Church.

Name: Louis Raphaël I Sako
Background: Cardinal Louis Raphaël I Sako is the Patriarch of Babylon of the Chaldeans and head of the Chaldean Catholic Church, an Eastern Catholic church in full communion with Rome. Born in Iraq in 1948, Sako has served as a leading figure for the Chaldean Christian community, especially amid significant persecution and displacement following the 2003 Iraq War and the rise of ISIS. He is recognized for advocating interfaith dialogue, national unity, and the protection of Iraq’s Christian minority, often voicing concerns about their declining numbers and political marginalization. Cardinal Sako promotes reconciliation among Iraq’s various religious and ethnic groups, emphasizing the importance of peace, coexistence, and religious freedom.

Name: Vinko Puljić
Background: Cardinal Vinko Puljić is a Bosnian Roman Catholic prelate who served as the Archbishop of Vrhbosna (Sarajevo) from 1990 to 2022 and was made a cardinal by Pope John Paul II in 1994. Born in 1945 in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Puljić is known for his efforts to promote interreligious dialogue and peace during and after the Bosnian War, advocating for the rights of Catholics and other minorities in a country marked by ethnic and religious divisions. He has consistently spoken out against nationalism, discrimination, and violence, emphasizing reconciliation, coexistence, and the importance of religious freedom in the Balkan region.

Name: Peter Turkson
Role_Office: Chancellor of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and the Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences
Background: Cardinal Peter Turkson, born in Ghana in 1948, is a prominent Catholic leader known for his deep commitment to social justice, interfaith dialogue, and environmental issues. Appointed as cardinal by Pope John Paul II in 2003, Turkson served as the president of the Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace and later as the first prefect of the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development under Pope Francis. He is recognized for his strong advocacy for the poor, his critique of global economic inequalities, and his support for climate action, notably contributing to Pope Francis’s encyclical *Laudato si’*. Turkson emphasizes the moral dimensions of economic, social, and environmental challenges, calling for solidarity, care for creation, and respect for human dignity worldwide.

Name: Josip Bozanić
Background: Cardinal Josip Bozanić is a Croatian Roman Catholic prelate who has served as the Archbishop of Zagreb since 1997 and was elevated to the cardinalate by Pope John Paul II in 2003. Known for his conservative stance on social issues, Bozanić is a vocal advocate of traditional Catholic values, emphasizing the importance of family, religious education, and opposition to abortion and same-sex marriage. He has played a significant role in public debates in Croatia, often encouraging dialogue between church and state while maintaining the church’s moral positions. Bozanić is also recognized for his efforts in promoting reconciliation and unity in Croatia following the tumultuous 1990s.

Name: Philippe Barbarin
Background: Cardinal Philippe Barbarin is a French Roman Catholic prelate, born in 1950, who served as the Archbishop of Lyon from 2002 to 2020. Known for his conservative theological views, he has been a vocal defender of traditional Catholic teachings on issues such as marriage and sexuality, notably opposing the legalization of same-sex marriage in France. Barbarin's tenure was marred by controversy due to his handling of sexual abuse cases within the Church, particularly his delayed response to allegations against a priest in his diocese, which led to his conviction (later overturned on appeal) for failing to report abuse. Despite these controversies, he remains influential in French Catholic circles for his doctrinal orthodoxy and advocacy for interfaith dialogue, particularly with the Jewish and Muslim communities.

Name: Péter Erdő
Background: Cardinal Péter Erdő is a Hungarian Roman Catholic prelate and theologian, born in 1952, who has served as the Archbishop of Esztergom-Budapest and Primate of Hungary since 2003. Holding doctorates in theology and canon law, Erdő is known for his scholarly background and leadership roles within the Church, including serving as President of the Council of European Bishops' Conferences. While considered doctrinally conservative, Erdő is noted for his pastoral sensitivity and pragmatic approach, advocating for dialogue within Europe and promoting the relevance of Christian values in a secular society. He is also recognized for his emphasis on traditional Catholic teachings, particularly regarding family and social issues, while remaining open to synodal discussions and greater engagement with contemporary challenges facing the Church.

Name: Stanisław Ryłko
Role_Office: Archpriest of the Papal Basilica of Saint Mary Major
Background: Cardinal Stanisław Ryłko is a Polish prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1945, who has played a prominent role in promoting lay participation within the Church. He was appointed president of the Pontifical Council for the Laity from 2003 until its merger into the Dicastery for the Laity, Family, and Life in 2016. Known for his strong advocacy of traditional Catholic values, Ryłko emphasizes the importance of Christian formation, the family, and a vibrant lay apostolate in the face of secularism. He upholds the Church’s teachings on moral and social issues and encourages Catholics to actively witness their faith in contemporary society.

Name: Francisco Robles Ortega
Background: Cardinal Francisco Robles Ortega is a Mexican prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1949 in Mascota, Jalisco. He was ordained a priest in 1976, later becoming Bishop of Toluca, Archbishop of Monterrey, and since 2011, Archbishop of Guadalajara. Created cardinal by Pope Benedict XVI in 2007, Robles Ortega is known for his pastoral focus, advocacy for social justice, and defense of migrants’ rights. He has expressed concerns about violence, corruption, and inequality in Mexico, calling for dialogue and ethical leadership. Orthodox in doctrine, he supports traditional Catholic teachings but is recognized for his pragmatic approach to social issues facing the Mexican Church.

Name: Daniel DiNardo
Background: Cardinal Daniel DiNardo is an American prelate of the Catholic Church, serving as the Archbishop of Galveston-Houston since 2006 and elevated to cardinal in 2007 by Pope Benedict XVI. Known for his pastoral approach and commitment to social justice, DiNardo has advocated for immigration reform, pro-life issues, and the protection of religious liberty. He has also faced criticism for his handling of clergy sexual abuse cases but has voiced support for stronger accountability and transparency in the Church. As former president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops (2016–2019), DiNardo played a key role in representing Catholic viewpoints on national policy and moral issues.

Name: Odilo Scherer
Background: Cardinal Odilo Scherer is a Brazilian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, serving as the Archbishop of São Paulo since 2007. Born in 1949 in Cerro Largo, Brazil, he has roots in German immigrant families and was ordained a priest in 1976. Scherer is noted for his moderate, pragmatic approach within the Church, balancing social justice concerns with doctrinal orthodoxy. He has been vocal about tackling corruption, poverty, and violence in Brazil, emphasizing the Church's role in addressing social issues. Generally considered a centrist, Scherer supports dialogue within the Church and society while upholding Church teachings on life and family.

Name: Robert Sarah
Role_Office: Prefect emeritus of the Congregation for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments
Background: Cardinal Robert Sarah is a Guinean prelate of the Catholic Church, known for his conservative theological views and his emphasis on traditional Catholic liturgy and moral teachings. Born in 1945 in Guinea, he became the youngest bishop in the world at age 34 and later served as Prefect of the Congregation for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments from 2014 to 2021. Sarah is a vocal advocate for reverent, traditional liturgy, including frequent support for the Latin Mass and the ad orientem celebration of the Eucharist. He is also known for his strong opposition to the secularization of society, gender ideology, and liberalizing trends within the Church, advocating instead for a return to spiritual discipline, prayer, and fidelity to Catholic doctrine.

Name: Raymond Leo Burke
Role_Office: Patron emeritus of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta
Background: Cardinal Raymond Leo Burke is an American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church known for his traditionalist and conservative views. Born in 1948, Burke served as bishop of La Crosse, Wisconsin, archbishop of St. Louis, and Prefect of the Apostolic Signatura, the Church’s highest court. He is noted for his strict adherence to Catholic doctrine on issues such as abortion, marriage, and liturgy, and has been a vocal critic of more progressive movements within the Church, particularly under Pope Francis. Burke opposes Communion for divorced and remarried Catholics and has questioned reforms related to LGBTQ+ issues, positioning himself as a leading figure among conservative Catholics globally.

Name: Kurt Koch
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Promoting Christian Unity
Background: Cardinal Kurt Koch is a Swiss prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, born in 1950, who has served as President of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity since 2010. Known for his deep theological expertise, Koch has been a champion of ecumenical dialogue, particularly with Orthodox and Protestant churches, emphasizing the importance of unity among Christians. He is regarded as the Vatican’s leading authority on Jewish-Christian relations, advocating for continued reconciliation and robust interfaith dialogue. Theologically, Koch is considered conservative, upholding traditional Catholic teachings, but he is also seen as open-minded in his commitment to fostering respectful, constructive conversations with other denominations and religions.

Name: Kazimierz Nycz
Background: Cardinal Kazimierz Nycz, born on February 1, 1950, in Stara Wieś, Poland, served as the Archbishop of Warsaw from 2007 until his retirement in November 2024. Ordained a priest in 1973, he earned a doctorate in catechetics and held various educational and pastoral roles before becoming a bishop in 1988. Elevated to cardinal in 2010, Nycz emphasized the universal nature of the Church, cautioning against its instrumentalization for national causes. In October 2024, he expressed openness to legal protections for same-sex civil unions in Poland, provided they are not equated with marriage. Additionally, he highlighted social issues, attributing rising poverty to the reluctance of the wealthy to share their resources. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazimierz_Nycz?utm_source=openai), [newwaysministry.org](https://www.newwaysministry.org/2024/12/12/polish-cardinal-now-open-to-legal-protections-for-lgbtq-couples/?utm_source=openai), [pap.pl](https://www.pap.pl/aktualnosci/news%2C1036832%2Ckardynal-kazimierz-nycz-podstawowa-przyczyna-rosnacego-ubostwa-jest?utm_source=openai))

Name: Malcolm Ranjith
Background: Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith, born in Sri Lanka in 1947, is the Archbishop of Colombo and a prominent leader in the Roman Catholic Church. Known for his traditionalist views, he has been an advocate for liturgical orthodoxy, supporting the Latin Mass and expressing concern over liberalizing trends within the Church. Ranjith has been vocal about political and social issues in Sri Lanka, particularly on human rights, justice, and reconciliation following the country's civil conflict. He is recognized for his critical stance on government corruption and for championing the needs and rights of the country's Catholic minority.

Name: Reinhard Marx
Role_Office: Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Coordinator of the Council for the Economy
Background: Cardinal Reinhard Marx is a prominent German Catholic prelate, serving as the Archbishop of Munich and Freising since 2007 and a member of Pope Francis’ Council of Cardinals. Known for his progressive stance within the Church, Marx advocates for greater inclusion, increased dialogue on social justice, and reform in areas such as clerical celibacy, the role of women, and the Church’s approach to LGBTQ+ individuals. He has called for institutional transparency and accountability, particularly in addressing the clerical sexual abuse crisis, and supports modernizing the Church to better engage with contemporary society while upholding core Christian values.

Name: João Braz de Aviz
Role_Office: Prefect emeritus of the Dicastery for Institutes of Consecrated Life and Societies of Apostolic Life
Background: Cardinal João Braz de Aviz is a Brazilian prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1947, who currently serves as the Prefect of the Dicastery for Institutes of Consecrated Life and Societies of Apostolic Life, a position he has held since 2011. Known for his pastoral sensitivity and openness, Braz de Aviz is recognized for promoting dialogue and reconciliation within religious communities, advocating for a return to the “spirit” of Vatican II with an emphasis on mercy, simplicity, and service. He has been praised for encouraging greater collaboration among different branches of religious life and for his efforts to heal divisions, especially those that arose between traditionalist groups and the Vatican. The cardinal is also seen as supportive of Pope Francis’ vision for a more inclusive and compassionate Church.

Name: Thomas Collins
Background: Cardinal Thomas Collins is a Canadian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church who served as the Archbishop of Toronto from 2007 to 2023. Born in 1947 in Guelph, Ontario, he has a background in theology and scripture, earning a Doctorate in Sacred Theology from the Pontifical Gregorian University. Known for his orthodox and traditional Catholic views, Collins has been outspoken on issues such as the sanctity of life, religious freedom, and the defense of traditional marriage. He often emphasizes the importance of scripture, charity, and fidelity to the teachings of the Church in contemporary society. Elevated to the College of Cardinals in 2012 by Pope Benedict XVI, Collins remains an influential voice in Canadian and global Catholicism.

Name: Wim Eijk
Background: Cardinal Wim Eijk is a Dutch prelate and the Archbishop of Utrecht since 2007. Originally trained as a medical doctor, Eijk later studied philosophy and theology, earning doctorates in both medical ethics and philosophy. Known for his conservative views within the Catholic Church, he staunchly upholds traditional doctrine on issues such as euthanasia, same-sex marriage, and communion for divorced and remarried Catholics. Eijk is recognized for his outspoken defense of Church teachings, advocating for clarity and orthodoxy in faith and morals, and has sometimes publicly disagreed with more liberal trends within the Church.

Name: Giuseppe Betori
Background: Cardinal Giuseppe Betori, born on February 25, 1947, in Foligno, Italy, is an Italian prelate who served as Archbishop of Florence from 2008 until his resignation in April 2024. Ordained a priest in 1970, he holds advanced degrees in theology and sacred scripture. Throughout his career, Betori has emphasized the importance of integrating faith and reason, advocating for dialogue between the Church and scientific communities. He has also expressed concern over declining priestly vocations, attributing this trend to broader societal shifts affecting personal commitments. Additionally, Betori has supported interfaith initiatives, including facilitating the sale of Church property for the construction of a mosque, underscoring his commitment to religious liberty and multicultural dialogue. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_betori_g.html?utm_source=openai), [catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/16122/dialogue-between-faith-and-reason-fundamental-says-archbishop-about-galileo-case?utm_source=openai), [catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/246008/cardinal-laments-lack-of-priestly-vocations-in-florentine-archdiocese?utm_source=openai), [onepeterfive.com](https://onepeterfive.com/florence-sell-mosque/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Timothy M. Dolan
Background: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan is the Archbishop of New York and a leading figure in the American Catholic Church, known for his charismatic personality and conservative yet pastoral approach to Catholic doctrine. Born in 1950 in St. Louis, Missouri, Dolan is recognized for his staunch defense of traditional church teachings on issues such as marriage, abortion, and religious liberty, often engaging in public debates on these topics. He is appreciated for his approachable style and advocacy for immigrant rights, religious freedom, and the sanctity of life, balancing a firm adherence to Catholic orthodoxy with a warm, engaging demeanor. As a past president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, Dolan has played a significant role in shaping Catholic discourse in the United States.

Name: Rainer Woelki
Background: Cardinal Rainer Maria Woelki is a German Roman Catholic prelate who has served as the Archbishop of Cologne since 2014. Known for his conservative theological and ecclesiastical stance, Woelki has maintained traditional Catholic teachings on issues such as sexuality, priestly celibacy, and church authority, often clashing with more progressive voices in the German church, especially during the ongoing Synodal Path discussions. He has also faced significant criticism and controversy over his handling of clergy sexual abuse cases, leading to public protests and even calls for his resignation, although he retains the support of some in the Vatican. Woelki is considered an influential, yet polarizing, figure within both the German church and broader Catholic hierarchy.

Name: James Michael Harvey
Role_Office: Archpriest of the Papal Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls
Background: Cardinal James Michael Harvey is an American prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1949 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Ordained a priest in 1975, he entered the Vatican’s diplomatic service, notably serving as Prefect of the Papal Household from 1998 to 2012. Created a cardinal by Pope Benedict XVI in 2012, Harvey is known for his administrative expertise and commitment to the Church’s service, but he has largely avoided public involvement in controversial doctrinal debates, maintaining a low profile among cardinals and emphasizing loyalty, discretion, and service to the papacy and the Vatican’s internal affairs.

Name: Baselios Cleemis
Role_Office: Major Archbishop of Trivandrum ( Syro-Malankara Church )
Background: Cardinal Baselios Cleemis is the Major Archbishop-Catholicos of the Syro-Malankara Catholic Church, based in Kerala, India, and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Benedict XVI in 2012, making him one of the youngest cardinals at the time. Known for his emphasis on dialogue, unity, and social harmony, Cardinal Cleemis advocates for interreligious understanding and the protection of minority rights, especially Christians in India. He is recognized for his commitment to social justice, peaceful coexistence, and fostering ecumenical relations among Christian denominations. His leadership is marked by a pastoral approach focused on compassion, inclusivity, and responding to contemporary socio-political challenges facing the church and wider society.

Name: Gerhard Ludwig Müller
Role_Office: Prefect emeritus of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith
Background: Cardinal Gerhard Ludwig Müller is a German theologian and former Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (2012–2017), appointed by Pope Benedict XVI. Known for his conservative theological views, Müller is a staunch defender of traditional Catholic doctrine on issues such as the indissolubility of marriage, Eucharistic discipline, and opposition to same-sex unions. He has often expressed concern about theological ambiguity and what he sees as the risk of relativism within the Church, and has occasionally voiced criticism of some aspects of Pope Francis's pastoral approach, particularly in matters of doctrine and moral teaching.

Name: Vincent Nichols
Background: Cardinal Vincent Nichols, born in 1945 in Liverpool, is the Archbishop of Westminster and the leading Catholic prelate in England and Wales. Known for his pragmatic and diplomatic approach, Nichols has spoken out on social issues including poverty, migration, and religious freedom, advocating Catholic teachings while engaging constructively with secular society. He supports traditional Catholic doctrine, but is recognized for fostering dialogue both within the Church and with other faith communities. Ordained in 1969, Nichols has served in various educational and pastoral roles, and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2014.

Name: Leopoldo Brenes
Background: Cardinal Leopoldo Brenes, born in 1949 in Nicaragua, has been a prominent figure in the Catholic Church, serving as Archbishop of Managua since 2005 and being elevated to cardinal in 2014. Throughout his tenure, he has consistently advocated for dialogue and reconciliation amid Nicaragua's sociopolitical crises, emphasizing respect for differences and the pursuit of peace through understanding. Despite facing criticism and persecution from the government, Brenes remains committed to fostering communication, urging for the release of political prisoners, and calling for a "change of direction" in the nation's political landscape. He underscores the importance of trust in divine guidance over human strategies, promoting hope and resilience among the faithful. ([catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/43198/nicaraguan-cardinal-peace-comes-from-dialogue-accepting-differences?utm_source=openai), [confidencial.digital](https://confidencial.digital/nacion/cardenal-leopoldo-brenes-aboga-por-la-libertad-de-los-presos-politicos/?utm_source=openai), [confidencial.digital](https://confidencial.digital/nacion/cardenal-leopoldo-brenes-llama-a-un-cambio-de-direccion-en-nicaragua/?utm_source=openai), [cruxnow.com](https://cruxnow.com/church-in-the-americas/2022/08/nicaraguan-cardinal-urges-trust-in-the-lord-as-crisis-continues?utm_source=openai))

Name: Gérald Lacroix ISPX
Background: Cardinal Gérald Cyprien Lacroix, ISPX, is a Canadian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church and a member of the Pius X Secular Institute. Born in 1957 in Saint-Hilaire-de-Dorset, Quebec, he became Archbishop of Quebec in 2011 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2014. Known for his pastoral and approachable style, Lacroix emphasizes the need for the Church to engage with contemporary society, focusing on social justice, outreach to the marginalized, and the importance of renewed evangelization. He aligns with Pope Francis’s priorities, supporting compassion, openness, and adaptation to modern realities while upholding Catholic doctrine.

Name: Jean-Pierre Kutwa
Background: Cardinal Jean-Pierre Kutwa, born on December 22, 1945, in Blockhauss, Ivory Coast, was ordained a priest in 1971 and later served as Archbishop of Gagnoa from 2001 to 2006, and then as Archbishop of Abidjan until his retirement in 2024. Elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2014, he has been a steadfast advocate for peace and reconciliation, especially during Ivory Coast's civil conflicts, urging dialogue, forgiveness, and unity among diverse communities. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Pierre_Kutwa?utm_source=openai), [catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/29101/ivory-coasts-new-cardinal-intends-to-advance-peace-in-his-country?utm_source=openai))

Name: Orani João Tempesta OCist
Role_Office: Archbishop of São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro
Background: Cardinal Orani João Tempesta, OCist, is a Brazilian Roman Catholic prelate and member of the Cistercian order, born on June 23, 1950, in São José do Rio Pardo, Brazil. He was ordained a priest in 1974 and later served as abbot before becoming bishop and archbishop in several Brazilian dioceses, including the Archdiocese of Rio de Janeiro, to which he was appointed in 2009. Created cardinal by Pope Francis in 2014, Cardinal Tempesta is known for his pastoral and inclusive approach, social engagement, and strong commitment to the needs of the poor and marginalized. He advocates for dialogue, unity, and human dignity, emphasizing the Church’s role in promoting peace and social justice, especially within the urban realities of Brazil.

Name: Mario Aurelio Poli
Background: Cardinal Mario Aurelio Poli is an Argentine prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, born in Buenos Aires in 1947. He was ordained a priest in 1978 and has held several academic and pastoral roles, becoming Archbishop of Buenos Aires in 2013, succeeding Jorge Mario Bergoglio (now Pope Francis). Created cardinal by Pope Francis the same year, Poli is known for his theological orthodoxy and pastoral sensitivity, often emphasizing social justice and dialogue. While generally aligned with Pope Francis’ focus on the marginalized, he is regarded as more conservative on doctrinal issues, supporting traditional Church teachings on matters such as marriage and abortion.

Name: Philippe Ouédraogo
Background: Cardinal Philippe Ouédraogo, born in 1945 in Burkina Faso, is a prominent Roman Catholic prelate known for his advocacy of peace, interreligious dialogue, and social justice. Appointed Archbishop of Ouagadougou in 2009 and made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2014, he has frequently spoken out on issues affecting Africa, including poverty, terrorism, and political instability. Cardinal Ouédraogo emphasizes the importance of education, reconciliation, and solidarity, and he encourages dialogue between Christians and Muslims in the region. He is recognized for his pastoral care, humility, and commitment to fostering harmony in a challenging socio-political context.

Name: Chibly Langlois
Background: Cardinal Chibly Langlois, born on November 29, 1958, in La Vallée, Haiti, is the first Haitian cardinal in history. Ordained a priest in 1991, he pursued advanced studies in pastoral theology at the Pontifical Lateran University in Rome. Appointed Bishop of Fort-Liberté in 2004 and later of Les Cayes in 2011, he became a cardinal in 2014 under Pope Francis. Langlois has been a vocal advocate for Haiti's economic development, emphasizing the need for self-sufficiency and the utilization of renewable energy sources. He has also expressed concerns about the influence of voodoo in Haitian society, viewing it as a significant social issue that offers "magic" but no real solutions to the country's challenges. ([ncronline.org](https://www.ncronline.org/haitis-first-cardinal-great-strides-have-been-made-country?utm_source=openai), [haitilibre.com](https://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-11594-haiti-religion-you-can-t-be-voodooist-and-catholic-dixit-mgr-langlois.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Manuel Clemente
Background: Cardinal Manuel Clemente is a prominent Portuguese Roman Catholic prelate, born in 1948 in Torres Vedras, Portugal. He has a reputation as an intellectual and historian, holding advanced degrees in theology and church history. Known for his moderate and pastoral approach, Clemente is seen as promoting dialogue within the Church and between the Church and broader society. As the Patriarch of Lisbon since 2013 and elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2015, he has supported social justice and the church’s engagement with contemporary issues, often stressing the importance of charity, inclusion, and a compassionate response to modern challenges facing both the Church and society.

Name: Berhaneyesus Demerew Souraphiel CM
Role_Office: Archbishop of Addis Abeba ( Ethiopian Church )
Background: Cardinal Berhaneyesus Demerew Souraphiel, CM, is an Ethiopian prelate of the Catholic Church and a member of the Congregation of the Mission (Vincentians). Born in 1948 in Cheleleqa, Ethiopia, he became Archbishop of Addis Ababa in 1999 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2015. Cardinal Souraphiel is recognized for his commitment to social justice, interreligious dialogue, and peacebuilding, often advocating for the rights of migrants and refugees in Africa. He is a prominent voice for the Catholic Church in Ethiopia, emphasizing reconciliation, humanitarian aid, and the protection of religious freedom.

Name: John Dew
Background: Cardinal John Dew is a New Zealand Roman Catholic prelate who served as the Archbishop of Wellington from 2005 to 2023 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2015. Known for his pastoral approach, Dew has been a strong advocate for a more inclusive and compassionate Church, emphasizing the need for mercy, openness, and dialogue, particularly regarding divorced and remarried Catholics and those marginalized by Church teachings. He has supported Pope Francis’s vision of a synodal and reform-oriented Church, calling for greater lay involvement and understanding of contemporary issues facing Catholics today.

Name: Charles Maung Bo SDB
Background: Cardinal Charles Maung Bo SDB is a Burmese Roman Catholic prelate and member of the Salesians of Don Bosco, known for his advocacy of peace, justice, and interfaith dialogue in Myanmar. Born in 1948, he became the first cardinal from Myanmar in 2015. Cardinal Bo has been a prominent voice for human rights, especially amid the country’s political turmoil, speaking out against violence, religious persecution, and ethnic conflicts—including the plight of the Rohingya. He emphasizes reconciliation, dialogue, and compassion, urging protection of minority rights and a commitment to democracy and social harmony.

Name: Kriengsak Kovitvanit
Background: Cardinal Francis Xavier Kriengsak Kovitvanit, born on June 27, 1949, in Bangkok, Thailand, is a prominent Thai Catholic prelate who served as Archbishop of Bangkok from 2009 until his resignation on June 27, 2024. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kriengsak_Kovitvanit?utm_source=openai)) Ordained a priest in 1976, he has been deeply involved in pastoral care, seminary education, and interreligious dialogue. Cardinal Kovitvanit emphasizes the importance of laypeople's witness in evangelization, asserting that the credibility of the Christian faith depends mainly on their testimony. ([licas.news](https://www.licas.news/2022/10/26/credibility-of-christianity-in-asia-depends-on-lay-witness-says-bangkoks-cardinal-kriengsak/?utm_source=openai)) He also highlights the Golden Rule as a foundation for successful interfaith dialogue, noting its presence across major religious texts. ([rvasia.org](https://www.rvasia.org/church-asia/golden-rule-key-successful-interreligious-dialogue-says-thai-cardinal?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, he views secularism as a significant challenge to the Church, describing it as the modern face of the devil. ([catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/31566/for-thailands-new-cardinal-secularism-is-the-face-of-the-devil?utm_source=openai))

Name: Francesco Montenegro
Background: Cardinal Francesco Montenegro is an Italian prelate born in 1946, known for his extensive pastoral experience and commitment to social justice, particularly regarding migrants and the poor. He served as Archbishop of Agrigento, a region heavily impacted by migration across the Mediterranean, and gained prominence for his compassionate response to refugee crises. Created cardinal by Pope Francis in 2015, Montenegro strongly advocates for welcoming migrants and addressing poverty, aligning closely with Pope Francis's emphasis on mercy and outreach to society's margins. His views consistently emphasize solidarity, inclusion, and the moral responsibility of the Church to defend human dignity.

Name: Daniel Sturla SDB
Background: Cardinal Daniel Sturla SDB is an Uruguayan Salesian priest and Archbishop of Montevideo, born in 1959. He became a cardinal in 2015, appointed by Pope Francis, and is known for his dynamic leadership within the Catholic Church in Uruguay—a country marked by secularism and low religious participation. Sturla is recognized for his advocacy of a more visible Church presence in public life and his efforts to engage youth and promote Catholic education. He often emphasizes dialogue, social outreach, and the importance of religious values in shaping society, while also upholding traditional Church teachings on moral and social issues.

Name: Arlindo Gomes Furtado
Role_Office: Bishop of Santiago de Cabo Verde
Background: Cardinal Arlindo Gomes Furtado, born on November 15, 1949, in Santa Catarina, Cape Verde, is a prominent Catholic prelate who has served as the Bishop of Santiago de Cabo Verde since 2009. Ordained a priest in 1976, he has held various roles, including rector of the São José Seminary and vicar general of the Santiago diocese. In 2003, he became the first Bishop of Mindelo and was appointed to his current position in 2009. Pope Francis elevated him to cardinal in 2015, making him the first Cape Verdean to hold this title. Cardinal Furtado emphasizes the importance of strong family ties, viewing the family as the foundation for faith and community, and advocates for the Church's role in fostering peace and fraternity. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2018-05/cape-verdean-cardinal-urges-strong-family-ties.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Soane Patita Paini Mafi
Background: Born on December 19, 1961, in Nukuʻalofa, Tonga, Cardinal Soane Patita Paini Mafi is the first Tongan to be appointed a cardinal, a position he assumed in 2015 at the age of 53, making him the youngest member of the College of Cardinals at that time. Raised in a devout Catholic family, he was ordained a priest in 1991 and became Bishop of Tonga in 2008. Cardinal Mafi emphasizes deepening faith, as reflected in his episcopal motto "Ke Loloto e Tui" ("Deepen the Faith"), and advocates for a humble yet passionate Church filled with the "fire of the Spirit." He is also a vocal advocate against climate change, highlighting its impact on low-lying Pacific regions, and expresses concern over globalization's effects on traditional Tongan culture, particularly the shift towards materialism and individualism. ([americamagazine.org](https://www.americamagazine.org/content/dispatches/our-church-has-shine-out-cardinal-elect-soane-patita-paini-mafi-tonga?utm_source=openai))

Name: Dieudonné Nzapalainga CSSp
Background: Cardinal Dieudonné Nzapalainga, a member of the Congregation of the Holy Spirit (CSSp), is the Archbishop of Bangui, Central African Republic. Born in 1967, he became the youngest cardinal appointed by Pope Francis in 2016. Nzapalainga is widely recognized for his peacebuilding efforts during the Central African Republic's civil conflict, notably promoting dialogue and reconciliation between Christians and Muslims. He advocates for social justice, interfaith harmony, and the protection of human dignity, emphasizing the Church’s role as a mediator and voice for the marginalized in his violence-stricken nation.

Name: Carlos Osoro Sierra
Background: Cardinal Carlos Osoro Sierra is a Spanish prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1945, known for his pastoral approach and moderate views. He served as Archbishop of Madrid from 2014 to 2023 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2016. Osoro is recognized for his emphasis on dialogue, inclusion, and social outreach, aligning with Pope Francis’s vision for a more compassionate and open Church. He has advocated for pastoral care over strict doctrinal enforcement, encouraged the participation of laypeople, and supported efforts to address social injustices, positioning himself as a bridge-builder within the Spanish Church and beyond.

Name: Sérgio da Rocha
Role_Office: Archbishop of São Salvador da Bahia
Background: Cardinal Sérgio da Rocha, born on October 21, 1959, in Dobrada, São Paulo, is a prominent Brazilian prelate who has served as Archbishop of São Salvador da Bahia since 2020 and was elevated to cardinal in 2016. His pastoral work emphasizes compassion and social justice, notably addressing violence against marginalized communities. In May 2021, he celebrated a Mass honoring victims of anti-LGBTQ violence, condemning societal indifference to such acts. ([newwaysministry.org](https://www.newwaysministry.org/2021/06/15/brazilian-cardinal-celebrates-memorial-mass-for-local-victims-of-anti-lgbtq-violence/?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, he has criticized the aggression prevalent on social media, urging Catholics to promote peace and fraternity. ([fides.org](https://www.fides.org/en/news/63821-AMERICA_BRAZIL_Cardinal_da_Rocha_Too_much_aggression_in_social_media_Also_Carnival_highlighted_the_violence?utm_source=openai)) His episcopal motto, "Omnia in Caritate" ("All in Love"), reflects his commitment to love and service. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A9rgio_da_Rocha?utm_source=openai))

Name: Blase J. Cupich
Background: Cardinal Blase J. Cupich, appointed as the Archbishop of Chicago in 2014 and elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2016, is known for his moderate and pastoral approach within the Catholic Church. He emphasizes dialogue, accompaniment, and inclusion, often aligning with Pope Francis on issues such as social justice, care for migrants, and environmental responsibility. Cupich has prioritized addressing the sexual abuse crisis with transparency and has supported pastoral flexibility on issues like communion for divorced and remarried Catholics. While respected for his openness, he has also faced criticism from more conservative Catholics for his progressive stances on issues related to LGBTQ inclusion, liturgical reform, and engagement with contemporary social issues.

Name: Jozef De Kesel
Background: Cardinal Jozef De Kesel is a Belgian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, born in 1947 in Ghent, Belgium, and ordained as a priest in 1972. He served as the Archbishop of Mechelen-Brussels from 2015 to 2023 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2016. Known for his progressive and conciliatory approach, De Kesel has advocated for a more open and inclusive Church, emphasizing dialogue with secular society and other faiths. He supports pastoral care for LGBTQ+ individuals, greater lay participation, and has shown cautious openness toward priestly celibacy debates, while also acknowledging the need for the Church to address its handling of abuse cases transparently and compassionately.

Name: Carlos Aguiar Retes
Background: Cardinal Carlos Aguiar Retes, born in 1950 in Tepic, Mexico, is a prominent Mexican prelate and currently the Archbishop of Mexico City. He is known for his progressive and pastoral approach, emphasizing dialogue, inclusivity, and the role of the laity in the Church. Aguiar Retes has supported Pope Francis’ agenda of reform, social justice, and engagement with contemporary issues facing society and the Church in Latin America. He has played a significant role in the Latin American Episcopal Conference (CELAM), advocating for the “New Evangelization” and a Church that listens to and accompanies people in their struggles, rather than one that simply imposes doctrine.

Name: John Ribat MSC
Background: Cardinal John Ribat, MSC, is a prominent Catholic leader from Papua New Guinea, born in 1957 in Volavolo. He is noted for being the first cardinal from his country, appointed by Pope Francis in 2016. As a member of the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart (MSC), Ribat is recognized for his deep commitment to social justice, environmental advocacy, and interreligious dialogue. He has been especially vocal about climate change, emphasizing its severe impact on Pacific island nations and urging global action to protect vulnerable communities. Ribat is also known for promoting peace, respect for indigenous cultures, and a compassionate, inclusive vision of the Catholic Church.

Name: Joseph W. Tobin CSsR
Background: Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin, CSsR, is an American prelate of the Catholic Church and a member of the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer (Redemptorists). Born in 1952 in Detroit, Michigan, he has served as the Archbishop of Newark since 2017 and was named a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2016. Known for his pastoral approach and commitment to social justice, Tobin is recognized for his advocacy for immigrants, support for LGBT Catholics, and efforts to promote inclusivity within the Church. He reflects the pastoral priorities of Pope Francis, emphasizing mercy, dialogue, and accompaniment, and has at times voiced cautious, nuanced positions on divisive issues, calling for compassion and understanding rather than exclusion.

Name: Juan José Omella
Background: Cardinal Juan José Omella, born in 1946 in Cretas, Spain, has served as Archbishop of Barcelona since 2015 and was elevated to cardinal in 2017. His pastoral career includes missionary work in Zaire and leadership roles in various Spanish dioceses. Omella is known for his commitment to social justice, emphasizing the Church's role in supporting the marginalized and advocating for the protection of family values. He has expressed that the Church should not align with political positions to avoid partisanship. In response to sexual abuse cases within the Church, Omella has publicly apologized and initiated independent audits to address the issue. He has also criticized legislative changes that liberalize abortion laws in Spain, describing them as "illogical." ([thetablet.co.uk](https://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/16670/cardinal-condemns-spain-abortion-law-reforms?utm_source=openai))

Name: Anders Arborelius OCD
Background: Cardinal Anders Arborelius, born in 1949 in Switzerland and raised in Sweden, is a Discalced Carmelite (OCD) and the first native Swede to become a Catholic bishop since the Reformation. Appointed Bishop of Stockholm in 1998 and created a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2017, Arborelius is widely recognized for his ecumenical outlook, commitment to dialogue with other Christian communities, and advocacy for migrants and social justice. His theological perspective is shaped by Carmelite spirituality, emphasizing contemplation, humility, and service, and he encourages the Catholic Church in Sweden to be a welcoming, inclusive presence in an overwhelmingly secular and Lutheran context.

Name: Angelo De Donatis
Background: Cardinal Angelo De Donatis, born in 1954 in Casarano, Italy, is an Italian prelate of the Catholic Church. He was appointed Cardinal Vicar of Rome by Pope Francis in 2017, making him responsible for the pastoral care of the Diocese of Rome. Known for his pastoral sensitivity and spiritual depth, De Donatis is considered a close ally of Pope Francis, supporting the Pope’s emphasis on mercy, pastoral accompaniment, and synodality within the Church. He advocates for a Church that is more inclusive, attentive to human frailty, and focused on direct pastoral engagement, particularly with young people and those on the margins.

Name: Joseph Coutts
Background: Cardinal Joseph Coutts, born in Karachi, Pakistan, in 1945, is a prominent Catholic leader known for his advocacy of interfaith harmony and religious tolerance. Serving as the Archbishop of Karachi and elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2018, Coutts has dedicated his ministry to promoting peace and understanding between Christians and Muslims in Pakistan, often amidst challenging conditions for religious minorities. He is recognized for his moderate views, commitment to dialogue, and efforts to uphold human rights and social justice, making him a respected voice for coexistence and compassion in a predominantly Muslim society.

Name: António Marto
Background: Cardinal António Marto is a Portuguese prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1947, who served as Bishop of Leiria-Fátima from 2006 to 2022. Known for his pastoral sensitivity and openness, Marto is recognized for his progressive views within the Church, notably his sympathy for Pope Francis' reforms and his willingness to address contemporary issues such as immigration, secularization, and the role of women in the Church. He has called for a more compassionate and listening Church, supported dialogue with non-believers, and advocated for the Church to respond to modern challenges with mercy and understanding rather than rigidity.

Name: Désiré Tsarahazana
Background: Cardinal Désiré Tsarahazana is a Malagasy prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, serving as the Archbishop of Toamasina in Madagascar. Born on June 13, 1954, he has played a significant role in the Catholic Church in Madagascar, advocating for social justice, poverty reduction, and improved education. Elevated to the cardinalate by Pope Francis in 2018, Tsarahazana is known for his commitment to dialogue, reconciliation, and the environment, reflecting the priorities of the broader Church in addressing the pressing needs of Madagascar’s people and the importance of global solidarity.

Name: Giuseppe Petrocchi
Background: Cardinal Giuseppe Petrocchi, born on August 19, 1948, in Ascoli Piceno, Italy, has had a distinguished career in the Catholic Church, marked by his dedication to pastoral care and education. Ordained a priest in 1973, he served in various capacities, including as a professor and parish priest, before being appointed Bishop of Latina-Terracina-Sezze-Priverno in 1998. In 2013, he became the Archbishop of L'Aquila, a region severely affected by earthquakes, where he focused on both physical reconstruction and spiritual renewal. Elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2018, Petrocchi has emphasized the importance of listening and empathy in ministry, advocating for a "Samaritan's sensitivity" that involves not only assisting others but truly understanding their situations. ([romereports.com](https://www.romereports.com/en/2018/07/11/giuseppe-petrocchi-cardinal-from-areas-devastated-by-earthquakes/?utm_source=openai)) His episcopal motto, "Ante omnia caritas" ("Above all, charity"), reflects his commitment to compassionate service. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_petrocchi_g.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Thomas Aquino Manyo Maeda
Background: Cardinal Thomas Aquino Manyo Maeda is a Japanese prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1949 in Tsuwasaki, Japan. He has served as Archbishop of Osaka and later of Osaka-Takamatsu, and was elevated to the College of Cardinals by Pope Francis in 2018. Maeda is known for his commitment to dialogue and reconciliation, particularly between Christians and other religious communities in Japan. He advocates for peace, nuclear disarmament, and care for marginalized people, drawing inspiration from Japanese Catholic history and the example of Christian martyrs. Cardinal Maeda emphasizes humility, compassion, and pastoral care, aligning his views closely with those of Pope Francis, especially on social justice and outreach to the peripheries.

Name: Ignatius Suharyo Hardjoatmodjo
Background: Cardinal Ignatius Suharyo Hardjoatmodjo is an Indonesian prelate of the Catholic Church who has served as the Archbishop of Jakarta since 2010 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019. Known for his commitment to interfaith dialogue, social justice, and peacebuilding, he emphasizes the importance of harmony in Indonesia’s diverse, predominantly Muslim society. Cardinal Suharyo advocates for a Church that is close to the people, respects local cultures, and actively contributes to national unity and pluralism, often speaking out against violence and intolerance while promoting the role of religion in fostering mutual respect and understanding.

Name: Juan García Rodríguez
Role_Office: Archbishop of San Cristóbal de la Habana
Background: Cardinal Juan de la Caridad García Rodríguez, born on July 11, 1948, in Camagüey, Cuba, is a prominent figure in the Cuban Catholic Church, known for his missionary zeal and commitment to social justice. Ordained in 1972, he served in various parishes before becoming Auxiliary Bishop of Camagüey in 1997 and Archbishop in 2002. In 2016, Pope Francis appointed him Archbishop of Havana, and he was elevated to cardinal in 2019. García Rodríguez has been instrumental in revitalizing the Church in Cuba, developing innovative catechesis programs that engage grandparents to teach Catholic principles to their grandchildren, and establishing prison ministries with government approval. He has expressed concern over the stagnation of dialogue between the Church and the Cuban government, advocating for greater understanding and cooperation. While he has not publicly taken a strong stance on issues like same-sex marriage, he co-signed a 2018 message from Cuban bishops criticizing the proposed constitutional definition of marriage as "the union of two persons," describing it as "mal founded and erroneous." ([washingtonblade.com](https://www.washingtonblade.com/2019/09/05/quien-es-juan-garcia-rodriguez-el-nuevo-cardenal-cubano-y-que-piensa-de-la-comunidad-lgbti/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Fridolin Ambongo Besungu OFMCap
Background: Cardinal Fridolin Ambongo Besungu OFMCap is a Congolese prelate and member of the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin, born in 1960. He serves as the Archbishop of Kinshasa in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and was named cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019. Renowned for his strong advocacy for peace, social justice, and environmental protection, Ambongo has been a vocal critic of political corruption and violence in the Congo, urging governmental responsibility and reforms. He is also a leading figure in the African Catholic Church, emphasizing the importance of the Church’s social mission and aligning closely with Pope Francis’s priorities regarding care for the poor, dialogue, and ecological concerns.

Name: Jean-Claude Hollerich SJ
Background: Cardinal Jean-Claude Hollerich SJ is a Luxembourgish Jesuit and Archbishop of Luxembourg, born in 1958. He is known for his progressive stance within the Catholic Church, particularly on issues such as LGBTQ+ inclusion and the role of women. Appointed by Pope Francis as the Relator General for the Synod on Synodality, Hollerich advocates for dialogue, greater openness, and reform-minded approaches within Church doctrine and practice. He is recognized for encouraging a listening Church and has suggested that Catholic teachings, especially about homosexuality, may need to evolve to reflect contemporary understanding.

Name: Álvaro Leonel Ramazzini Imeri
Background: Cardinal Álvaro Leonel Ramazzini Imeri is a Guatemalan Roman Catholic prelate known for his advocacy on social justice, indigenous rights, and environmental issues. Born in 1947 and ordained a priest in 1971, he has served as Bishop of San Marcos and later of Huehuetenango, focusing on defending marginalized communities against exploitation, particularly by mining interests. Cardinal Ramazzini is recognized for his outspoken criticism of corruption and human rights abuses, often facing threats for his activism. Created a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019, he is seen as a leading voice within the Church for the poor and the protection of creation, in line with the Pope’s emphasis on social and environmental justice.

Name: Matteo Zuppi
Background: Cardinal Matteo Zuppi is an Italian prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1955, who has served as the Archbishop of Bologna since 2015 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019. He is closely associated with the Community of Sant’Egidio, a Catholic lay association known for its work in peacebuilding, interreligious dialogue, and social justice. Zuppi is recognized for his progressive views on issues such as immigration, poverty, and inclusivity, and he supports the Church being open and welcoming to all. Throughout his ministry, he has emphasized dialogue, compassion for marginalized groups, and a pastoral approach that aligns closely with Pope Francis' vision of a more merciful and outward-looking Church.

Name: Cristóbal López Romero SDB
Background: Cardinal Cristóbal López Romero SDB, born in Spain in 1952, is a member of the Salesians of Don Bosco and has dedicated much of his life to education and missionary work, particularly in North Africa. Appointed Archbishop of Rabat, Morocco, in 2017 and elevated to cardinal in 2019 by Pope Francis, he is known for his strong commitment to interreligious dialogue, especially with Islam, and for advocating the rights and dignity of migrants and the marginalized. López Romero emphasizes a Church that serves as a bridge-builder and promotes peace, tolerance, and respect among different cultures and faiths, reflecting Pope Francis' vision of inclusion and outreach to the peripheries.

Name: Antoine Kambanda
Background: Cardinal Antoine Kambanda is a Rwandan Roman Catholic prelate who became the Archbishop of Kigali in 2018 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2020, the first Rwandan to receive this honor. Born in 1958, Kambanda survived the 1994 Rwandan genocide, which claimed the lives of many of his family members. Known for his commitment to reconciliation and healing in post-genocide Rwanda, he strongly emphasizes forgiveness, peace-building, and the Church's role in fostering unity. Kambanda is also recognized for supporting social justice, advocating for youth engagement, and encouraging a faith deeply integrated with daily life and national development.

Name: Wilton Daniel Gregory
Background: Cardinal Wilton Daniel Gregory, the Archbishop of Washington since 2019, is the first African American cardinal in U.S. history. Born in Chicago in 1947, Gregory was ordained a priest in 1973 and rose to prominence as Bishop of Belleville and later as Archbishop of Atlanta. Known for his moderate and pastoral approach, Gregory advocates for racial justice, inclusivity, and healing within the Catholic Church, particularly in response to the sexual abuse crisis. He often emphasizes dialogue, unity, and a welcoming stance toward marginalized groups, aligning with Pope Francis’s focus on compassion, social justice, and care for the vulnerable.

Name: Jose Advincula OP
Background: Cardinal Jose F. Advincula, O.P., is a Filipino prelate of the Roman Catholic Church who was appointed as the Archbishop of Manila in 2021. Born in 1952 in Capiz, Philippines, he was ordained a priest in 1976 and has served in various pastoral and academic roles, including as rector, seminary professor, and bishop of San Carlos and Capiz. Known for his humility and pastoral focus, Cardinal Advincula has emphasized synodality, inclusivity, and caring for marginalized communities in his ministries. He is also recognized for supporting reforms within the Church and promoting dialogue, charity, and social justice, especially in the context of poverty and human rights issues in the Philippines.

Name: Augusto Paolo Lojudice
Role_Office: Archbishop of Siena–Colle di Val d'Elsa–Montalcino and Bishop of Montepulciano–Chiusi–Pienza
Background: Cardinal Augusto Paolo Lojudice is an Italian prelate born in Rome in 1964, known for his dedication to social justice, especially regarding migrants, the marginalized, and the poor. Ordained a priest in 1991, he has served in various pastoral roles in Rome, focusing on outreach to the disadvantaged. Elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2020, Lojudice is recognized for his advocacy for migrant rights and outspoken criticism of racism and exclusionary policies. He emphasizes the Church’s mission to serve society’s most vulnerable and often calls for concrete action to support immigrants and marginalized communities, aligning closely with Pope Francis’s vision of a compassionate, inclusive, and socially engaged Church.

Name: Jean-Marc Aveline
Background: Cardinal Jean-Marc Aveline is a French prelate of the Catholic Church, born in Algeria in 1958 and raised in France. He has served as the Archbishop of Marseille since 2019 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2022. Aveline is recognized for his commitment to interreligious dialogue, particularly among Christians, Jews, and Muslims, and his advocacy for immigrant and marginalized communities, reflecting Marseille's diverse population. He supports an inclusive, dialogical Church that engages with social issues, promotes fraternity, and pursues peace, closely aligning with Pope Francis's vision of a synodal, outward-facing Catholicism.

Name: Peter Okpaleke
Background: Cardinal Peter Okpaleke is a Nigerian Roman Catholic prelate born in 1963, known for his resilience and commitment to reconciliation amid church conflicts. Appointed Bishop of Ahiara in 2012, his assignment faced strong local resistance, prompting his resignation in 2018. In 2020, Pope Francis appointed him as the first Bishop of Ekwulobia. Elevated to the cardinalate in 2022, Okpaleke is recognized for advocating dialogue, unity, and humility within the church, emphasizing fidelity to church authority and service to all, especially in the face of ethnic and regional tensions within Nigerian Catholicism.

Name: Leonardo Ulrich Steiner OFM
Background: Cardinal Leonardo Ulrich Steiner, OFM, is a Brazilian Franciscan friar and the Archbishop of Manaus, elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2022. Born in 1950 in Forquilhinha, Brazil, Steiner is known for his advocacy on behalf of the Amazonian peoples and the environment, reflecting Pope Francis's priorities. Deeply committed to social justice, he played a significant role in the Synod for the Amazon, urging the Church to listen to indigenous communities and defend their lands. Steiner emphasizes dialogue, humility, and ecological responsibility, aligning with a pastoral approach that prioritizes the marginalized and the care of creation.

Name: Filipe Neri Ferrão
Role_Office: Archbishop of Goa and Daman and Patriarch of the East Indies
Background: Cardinal Filipe Neri Ferrão, born in 1953 in Aldona, Goa, is the Archbishop of Goa and Daman and the Patriarch of the East Indies, a prominent figure in the Indian Catholic Church. Appointed bishop in 2003, Ferrão is known for advocating social harmony, interfaith dialogue, and the protection of minority rights, particularly the Christian community in India. He has voiced concerns about religious intolerance and emphasized the importance of constitutional values and secularism. Elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2022, Ferrão is respected for his pastoral leadership, commitment to social justice, and efforts to preserve the cultural and spiritual heritage of his Goan Catholic community.

Name: Robert W. McElroy
Background: Cardinal Robert W. McElroy, appointed cardinal by Pope Francis in 2022, is the Bishop of San Diego and known for his progressive and pastoral approach within the Catholic Church. Born in San Francisco in 1954, he has an academic background from Harvard, Stanford, and the Gregorian University in Rome. McElroy is recognized for advocating greater inclusion, particularly towards LGBTQ Catholics, and prioritizing issues like poverty, immigration, and environmental justice. He emphasizes dialogue, conscience, and accompaniment over culture-war politics, often aligning with Pope Francis’s vision of a more merciful and outward-facing Church.

Name: Virgílio do Carmo da Silva SDB
Background: Cardinal Virgílio do Carmo da Silva SDB is an East Timorese Roman Catholic prelate and member of the Salesians of Don Bosco. Born in 1967 in Venilale, Timor-Leste, he became the first cardinal in the history of his country in 2022. Known for his deep pastoral commitment and advocacy for social justice, education, and peace, Cardinal da Silva has played a pivotal role in promoting reconciliation and nation-building in post-independence Timor-Leste. He emphasizes the Church’s role in fostering unity, dialogue, and addressing the needs of the marginalized, focusing especially on youth empowerment and interfaith cooperation.

Name: Oscar Cantoni
Background: Cardinal Oscar Cantoni, born on September 1, 1950, in Lenno, Italy, was ordained a priest in 1975 and has served as Bishop of Crema (2005–2016) and Bishop of Como since 2016. Elevated to the cardinalate by Pope Francis in August 2022, he is known for his pastoral focus on youth and the marginalized, exemplified by initiating Italy's first diocesan 'youth mission' in 2010, which extended outreach beyond traditional church settings. His episcopal motto, "Fare di Cristo il cuore del mondo" ("Make Christ the heart of the world"), reflects his commitment to integrating Christ into all aspects of life. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oscar_Cantoni?utm_source=openai))

Name: Anthony Poola
Background: Cardinal Anthony Poola, born on November 15, 1961, in Poluru, Andhra Pradesh, India, is the first Dalit and Telugu-speaking cardinal in the Catholic Church. Ordained a priest in 1992, he served in various pastoral roles before being appointed Bishop of Kurnool in 2008 and Archbishop of Hyderabad in 2020. Elevated to the College of Cardinals by Pope Francis in 2022, Cardinal Poola is dedicated to serving marginalized communities, particularly the Dalits, emphasizing education and social empowerment as means to uplift the poor. He aspires to be a "missionary of compassion," focusing on aiding impoverished children and advocating for the rights of the underprivileged. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2022-06/dalit-india-consistory-cardinal-anthony-poola-interview.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Paulo Cezar Costa
Background: Cardinal Paulo Cezar Costa, born in 1967 in Valença, Brazil, is a prominent figure in the Catholic Church, currently serving as the Archbishop of Brasília, and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2022. Known for his academic background in theology, Costa earned a doctorate in dogmatic theology from the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome and has served as a seminary rector and professor. He is recognized for his commitment to dialogue, inclusion, and pastoral outreach, reflecting Pope Francis’s vision for a more synodal and compassionate Church. Costa advocates for social justice, environmental care, and the active engagement of the Church in addressing Brazil's social inequalities.

Name: William Goh
Background: Cardinal William Goh, born in Singapore in 1957, is the Archbishop of Singapore and became the country’s first cardinal in August 2022. Known for his pastoral dedication, Goh emphasizes the importance of building a vibrant, missionary, and inclusive Church community. He advocates for the Church’s engagement with society while upholding traditional Catholic teachings, especially on social and moral issues. Goh encourages interreligious dialogue and national unity in Singapore’s multicultural context, calling for Catholics to be compassionate, morally steadfast, and actively involved in public life, always guided by love and respect for others.

Name: Adalberto Martínez Flores
Background: Cardinal Adalberto Martínez Flores, born on July 8, 1951, in Asunción, Paraguay, is the first Paraguayan cardinal, appointed by Pope Francis in August 2022. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_martinezflores_a.html?utm_source=openai)) He studied economics at the Universidad Nacional de Asunción and theology at the Pontifical Lateran University in Rome. Ordained a priest in 1985, he served in various capacities, including as Bishop of San Lorenzo and Military Ordinary of Paraguay, before becoming Archbishop of Asunción in 2022. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adalberto_Mart%C3%ADnez_Flores?utm_source=openai)) Cardinal Martínez Flores is known for his strong stance against corruption and organized crime, emphasizing the need for transparency and justice in Paraguayan society. He advocates for communication rooted in truth, goodness, and beauty to foster dialogue and unity. ([adn.celam.org](https://adn.celam.org/cardenal-martinez-flores-el-pueblo-paraguayo-sufre-graves-amenazas-a-su-institucionalidad-por-el-avance-de-la-corrupcion-y-el-crimen-organizado/?utm_source=openai), [adn.celam.org](https://adn.celam.org/cardenal-martinez-flores-una-comunicacion-basada-en-la-verdad-la-bondad-y-la-belleza-construye-puentes-de-dialogo/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Giorgio Marengo IMC
Background: Cardinal Giorgio Marengo, IMC, is an Italian Roman Catholic missionary and member of the Consolata Missionaries (IMC). Born in 1974, he has spent most of his pastoral career in Mongolia, where he became the youngest cardinal in the world after being elevated by Pope Francis in 2022. As Prefect Apostolic of Ulaanbaatar, Marengo is known for his deep commitment to interreligious dialogue, cultural sensitivity, and the promotion of peace and encounter between different faiths. He emphasizes humility, simplicity, and a pastoral approach anchored in listening and accompaniment, reflecting Pope Francis’s vision for a "missionary church" focused on the peripheries.

Name: Pierbattista Pizzaballa OFM
Background: Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa, OFM, is an Italian Franciscan friar and the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, appointed in 2020 and elevated to cardinal in 2023. He has a deep background in interfaith dialogue and Middle Eastern affairs, having previously served as Custos of the Holy Land. Pizzaballa is known for advocating peace, coexistence, and religious freedom in the fraught Israeli-Palestinian context. He often emphasizes the importance of maintaining a Christian presence in the Holy Land and encourages dialogue among Christians, Jews, and Muslims. He has publicly called for nonviolence, humanitarian support, and respect for human dignity amid ongoing conflict in the region.

Name: Stephen Brislin
Background: Cardinal Stephen Brislin, born on September 24, 1956, in Welkom, South Africa, has served as a priest since 1983, later becoming Bishop of Kroonstad in 2006, Archbishop of Cape Town in 2009, and Archbishop of Johannesburg in 2024. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_brislin_s.html?utm_source=openai)) Elevated to cardinal in 2023, he has been a vocal advocate for inclusivity within the Church, emphasizing that it "should be home for gay people." ([newwaysministry.org](https://www.newwaysministry.org/2017/12/09/south-african-archbishop-says-church-home-gay-people/?utm_source=openai)) He also prioritizes healing the wounds of apartheid, fostering interfaith collaboration to address societal challenges. ([romereports.com](https://www.romereports.com/en/2023/10/03/south-african-cardinal-prioritizes-healing-wounds-of-apartheid/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Ángel Sixto Rossi SJ
Background: Cardinal Ángel Sixto Rossi, SJ, born on August 11, 1958, in Córdoba, Argentina, is a Jesuit priest and Archbishop of Córdoba since 2021. Ordained in 1986, he founded the Manos Abiertas Foundation in 1992, aiding the poor across ten Argentine cities. A close associate of Pope Francis, Rossi emphasizes humility and service, viewing the cardinalate as a role of service rather than power. He opposes abortion, considering it a broader societal issue, and actively campaigns against drug trafficking and violence, particularly concerning youth vulnerability. Rossi advocates for listening, dialogue, and discernment within the Church, aligning with the principles of the Synod on Synodality. ([collegeofcardinalsreport.com](https://collegeofcardinalsreport.com/cardinals/angel-sixto-rossi/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Luis José Rueda Aparicio
Background: Cardinal Luis José Rueda Aparicio is a Colombian prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1962 in San Gil, Santander. He currently serves as the Archbishop of Bogotá and was elevated to the rank of cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. Known for his strong advocacy for peace and social justice, Cardinal Rueda Aparicio has actively promoted dialogue, reconciliation, and the protection of human rights in Colombia, especially in the context of the country’s armed conflict and socio-political challenges. He emphasizes the importance of caring for the poor and marginalized, and supports the teachings of Pope Francis regarding environmental stewardship and the integral development of society.

Name: Grzegorz Ryś
Background: Cardinal Grzegorz Ryś, born on February 9, 1964, in Kraków, Poland, has served as the Archbishop of Łódź since 2017 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. An accomplished historian and theologian, he earned his doctorate in 1994 with a focus on medieval Polish piety and later specialized in the study of Jan Hus. Ryś is a proponent of synodality, emphasizing the Church's communal experience of faith and advocating for liturgical reforms that encourage active participation from all members, moving away from a solely priest-centered approach. He underscores the importance of pastoral care for LGBTQ individuals, distinguishing between doctrinal teachings and compassionate treatment. Additionally, Ryś has been critical of unfair criticisms directed at Pope Francis, urging a more comprehensive understanding of the pontiff's messages. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grzegorz_Ry%C5%9B?utm_source=openai), [english.katholisch.de](https://english.katholisch.de/artikel/57877-cardinal-rys-synodality-belongs-to-the-church-like-hierarchy?utm_source=openai), [english.katholisch.de](https://english.katholisch.de/artikel/47618-polish-cardinal-criticism-of-pope-francis-is-unfair?utm_source=openai))

Name: Stephen Ameyu Martin Mulla
Background: Cardinal Stephen Ameyu Martin Mulla is a South Sudanese Catholic prelate born in 1964, who has served as the Archbishop of Juba since 2019 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in September 2023. Known for his commitment to peace, reconciliation, and nation-building in a country long afflicted by civil conflict, Ameyu emphasizes dialogue and inclusivity both within the Church and in broader society. He advocates for the role of the Church in fostering unity and supporting displaced persons, and his leadership is characterized by a focus on healing ethnic divisions and advancing social justice in South Sudan.

Name: José Cobo Cano
Background: Cardinal José Cobo Cano, born in 1965 in Sabiote, Spain, is a Spanish prelate who became the Archbishop of Madrid in 2023, succeeding Cardinal Carlos Osoro. Originally a labor lawyer before his ordination in 1994, Cobo has been known for his social activism, especially regarding migrants, human rights, and outreach to marginalized communities. Considered part of the progressive wing of the Spanish Church, he is a strong supporter of Pope Francis’ vision, emphasizing social justice, synodality, and dialogue with contemporary society. His relatively young age and non-traditional rise—he became a cardinal without having led a diocese—signal Pope Francis’s aim of promoting pastors with a “smell of the sheep” and a commitment to renewal within the Church.

Name: Protase Rugambwa
Background: Cardinal Protase Rugambwa, born on May 31, 1960, in Bunena, Tanzania, has had a distinguished career within the Catholic Church, culminating in his appointment as Metropolitan Archbishop of Tabora in November 2023. Ordained a priest in 1990, he served in various pastoral and academic roles before becoming Bishop of Kigoma in 2008. His tenure in the Roman Curia included positions as Adjunct Secretary and later Secretary of the Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples. Elevated to the College of Cardinals by Pope Francis in September 2023, Cardinal Rugambwa emphasizes the importance of unity, love, and solidarity among Tanzanians and advocates for a partnership of equals between the churches in Africa and Europe to effectively spread the faith. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2023-10/cardinal-protase-rugambwa-invites-tanzanians-to-build-a-culture.html?utm_source=openai), [english.katholisch.de](https://english.katholisch.de/artikel/58960-cardinal-it-is-not-enough-if-churches-in-africa-are-just-full?utm_source=openai))

Name: Sebastian Francis
Background: Cardinal Dato' Seri Sebastian Francis, born on November 11, 1951, in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, has been the Bishop of Penang since 2011 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis on September 30, 2023. He completed his theological studies at the Major Seminary of Penang and the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas in Rome, earning a licentiate in dogmatic theology. Throughout his ministry, Cardinal Francis has emphasized unity within the Church, cautioning against divisive labels such as "traditional" or "liberal," and advocating for open, inclusive dialogue guided by the Holy Spirit. ([cruxnow.com](https://cruxnow.com/interviews/2023/08/new-malaysia-cardinal-cautions-against-fomenting-division-at-synod?utm_source=openai)) He has also served as President of the Catholic Bishops' Conference of Malaysia, Singapore, and Brunei from 2017 to 2023, and as Chairman of the Federation of Asian Bishops' Conferences' Office of Social Communication since 2023. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_francis_s.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Stephen Chow Sau-yan SJ
Background: Cardinal Stephen Chow Sau-yan, SJ, is a Hong Kong-born Jesuit priest, educator, and psychologist who was appointed Bishop of Hong Kong in 2021 and made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. A graduate of the University of Minnesota and Harvard University, Chow has served as provincial of the Chinese Province of the Society of Jesus and head of Wah Yan College, Hong Kong. Known for his moderate and pragmatic views, he emphasizes dialogue, reconciliation, and bridge-building between China and the Vatican, advocating for respect, religious freedom, and deeper understanding amid political tensions. Chow is recognized for promoting youth engagement, spiritual formation, and social justice, urging Catholics to contribute positively to society while remaining faithful to their beliefs.

Name: François-Xavier Bustillo OFMConv
Background: Cardinal François-Xavier Bustillo, OFMConv, is a Spanish-born Franciscan Conventual friar and the current Bishop of Ajaccio, Corsica, appointed by Pope Francis and elevated to cardinal in 2023. Known for his pastoral focus on welcoming, accompaniment, and spiritual renewal, Bustillo emphasizes a Church open to dialogue, attentive to the marginalized, and rooted in Franciscan values of humility and fraternity. He advocates for clergy living with authenticity and joy, addressing the modern world by being present and listening to people’s needs, and stresses the importance of community, mercy, and active witness in faith.

Name: Américo Aguiar
Background: Cardinal Américo Manuel Alves Aguiar, born on December 12, 1973, in Leça do Balio, Portugal, has rapidly ascended within the Catholic Church, serving as auxiliary bishop of Lisbon from 2019 to 2023 and currently as bishop of Setúbal since September 2023. He played a pivotal role as president of the World Youth Day 2023 Foundation, overseeing the event that attracted over 1.5 million attendees. Known for his communication skills and crisis management, Aguiar has emphasized the importance of dialogue and mutual respect among diverse groups. His statement that World Youth Day aims to foster unity without the intent to convert participants to Catholicism sparked debate, highlighting his focus on inclusivity. Additionally, his participation in a Portuguese Communist Party rally underscored his commitment to engaging with various societal sectors to address common concerns. ([catholicmasses.org](https://catholicmasses.org/portuguese-cardinal-defends-his-decision-to-take-part-in-communist-party-rally-national-catholic-register/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Carlos Castillo Mattasoglio
