Background: Cardinal Carlos Castillo Mattasoglio, born in Lima in 1950, is a Peruvian theologian and prelate known for his progressive views and commitment to social justice. After earning degrees in philosophy and theology from the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome, he was ordained a priest in 1984. He has served as a theology professor at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru since 1987 and held various pastoral roles, including parish vicar and national youth pastoral advisor. Appointed Archbishop of Lima in 2019 and elevated to cardinal in 2024, Castillo has been an outspoken critic of political corruption and institutional paralysis in Peru, advocating for reforms that align with the needs of the populace. He has also proposed innovative ecclesiastical changes, such as allowing laypeople to administer parishes, reflecting his vision of a more inclusive and egalitarian Church. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Castillo_Mattasoglio?utm_source=openai), [catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/248671/lima-archbishop-proposes-replacing-priests-with-laity-as-pastors?utm_source=openai))

Name: Vicente Bokalic Iglic CM
Background: Cardinal Vicente Bokalic Iglic, born on June 11, 1952, in Lanús, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, is the son of Slovenian immigrants who arrived in 1949. He joined the Congregation of the Mission (Vincentians) in 1970, taking his final vows in 1976, and was ordained a priest in 1978. His pastoral work includes roles as a missionary, parish priest, and formator within his order. Appointed auxiliary bishop of Buenos Aires in 2010, he became bishop of Santiago del Estero in 2013. In July 2024, Pope Francis elevated Santiago del Estero to an archdiocese, naming Bokalic its first archbishop and Primate of Argentina. He was created cardinal on December 7, 2024, with the title of Santa Maria Maddalena in Campo Marzio. Known for his commitment to evangelizing the poor, as reflected in his episcopal motto "Me envió a evangelizar a los pobres" ("He sent me to evangelize the poor"), Bokalic emphasizes humility, service, and a deep connection with marginalized communities. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicente_Bokalic_Iglic?utm_source=openai))

Name: Luis Cabrera Herrera OFM
Background: Cardinal Luis Gerardo Cabrera Herrera, O.F.M., born on October 11, 1955, in Azogues, Ecuador, is a Franciscan friar and the Archbishop of Guayaquil. He studied philosophy and theology at the Pontifical Catholic University of Ecuador and earned a doctorate in philosophy from the Pontifical University Antonianum in Rome. Ordained a priest in 1983, Cabrera has held various leadership roles within the Franciscan Order and the Ecuadorian Episcopal Conference. Appointed Archbishop of Cuenca in 2009 and later of Guayaquil in 2015, he was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis on December 7, 2024. Known for his commitment to dialogue and peace, Cabrera has been a vocal critic of abortion and gender ideology, emphasizing the importance of traditional family values while advocating for respect and inclusion of all individuals. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_cabrera_g.html?utm_source=openai), [collegeofcardinalsreport.com](https://collegeofcardinalsreport.com/cardinals/cardinal-luis-gerardo-cabrera-herrera-o-f-m/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Fernando Chomalí Garib
Background: Cardinal Fernando Chomalí Garib, born in 1957 in Santiago, Chile, is a prominent Roman Catholic leader, currently serving as the Archbishop of Santiago as of 2023. Of Palestinian and Italian descent, Chomalí is known for his background in bioethics, having earned a doctorate in the field from the Pontifical Gregorian University. Throughout his clerical career, he has been noted for his emphasis on social justice, ethical issues, and the Church's role in public life. Chomalí is regarded as a moderate voice in the Chilean Church, advocating for dialogue, transparency, and pastoral care, particularly in addressing issues of clerical abuse and societal inequality.

Name: Tarcisio Isao Kikuchi SVD
Background: Cardinal Tarcisio Isao Kikuchi, SVD, is a Japanese Roman Catholic prelate and member of the Society of the Divine Word (SVD). Born in 1958, he has served as the Archbishop of Tokyo since 2017 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. With a background in missionary work, particularly in Ghana, Kikuchi is known for his advocacy on issues such as peace, poverty alleviation, and the protection of migrants and refugees. As a prominent voice in the Asian Catholic Church, he emphasizes dialogue, social justice, and the Church's mission to serve the marginalized, reflecting his commitment to both humanitarianism and intercultural understanding.

Name: Pablo Virgilio David
Background: Cardinal Pablo Virgilio David is a prominent Filipino Catholic prelate, currently serving as the Bishop of Kalookan and president of the Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines (CBCP). Known for his strong social justice advocacy, he has been an outspoken critic of human rights abuses, particularly those linked to the Philippine government's controversial war on drugs under President Rodrigo Duterte. David emphasizes pastoral care, the defense of the marginalized, and a compassionate, inclusive approach to Church leadership. He is recognized for his intellectual background as a Bible scholar and for his commitment to dialogue and reconciliation in the face of political and social divisions.

Name: Ladislav Nemet SVD
Background: Cardinal Ladislav Német SVD is a Serbian Roman Catholic prelate of Hungarian descent, born in 1956. A member of the Society of the Divine Word (SVD), he has served as bishop of Zrenjanin and was appointed Archbishop of Belgrade in 2022. Német is known for his commitment to ecumenism, interfaith dialogue, and minority rights, reflecting his expertise in Central European multiculturalism and Catholic social teaching. He supports a Church engaged with social issues and advocates for mutual respect and cooperation among Serbia’s diverse religious and ethnic communities. Pope Francis elevated him to cardinal in 2023, underlining his reputation as a bridge-builder in the Balkan region.

Name: Jaime Spengler OFM
Background: Cardinal Jaime Spengler, OFM, is a Brazilian prelate of the Catholic Church and a member of the Order of Friars Minor (Franciscans). Born in 1960 in Gaspar, Santa Catarina, Brazil, he was ordained a priest in 1990 and later became Archbishop of Porto Alegre in 2013. Elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023, Spengler is known for his commitment to social justice, dialogue, and the defense of the poor, reflecting Franciscan values. Within the Brazilian Church, he is seen as a moderate voice advocating for unity, peace, and a Church engaged with contemporary societal issues, particularly the challenges facing Brazil and Latin America.

Name: Ignace Bessi Dogbo
Background: Cardinal Ignace Bessi Dogbo, born on August 17, 1961, in Niangon-Adjamé, Ivory Coast, has held significant positions within the Catholic Church, including Bishop of Katiola (2004–2021), Archbishop of Korhogo (2021–2024), and Archbishop of Abidjan since May 2024. He was created a cardinal by Pope Francis on December 7, 2024. An advocate for clergy accountability, in 2018, he criticized priests who, after serving in Fidei donum missions abroad, refused to return to their home dioceses. ([fr.wikipedia.org](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignace_Bessi_Dogbo?utm_source=openai))

Name: Jean-Paul Vesco OP
Background: Cardinal Jean-Paul Vesco, OP, born in Lyon, France, in 1962, is a Dominican friar and Archbishop of Algiers, known for his progressive views within the Catholic Church. After practicing law for seven years, he joined the Dominican Order in 1995 and was ordained a priest in 2001. His ministry in Algeria began in 2002, leading to his appointment as Bishop of Oran in 2012 and Archbishop of Algiers in 2021. Elevated to cardinal in December 2024, Vesco has advocated for re-evaluating the Church's stance on divorced and remarried Catholics, calling the previous discipline an "enormous injustice." ([freerepublic.com](https://freerepublic.com/focus/f-religion/4284319/posts?utm_source=openai)) He supports interfaith dialogue, emphasizing human fraternity over conversion efforts, and has expressed openness to expanding women's roles within the Church, including the possibility of a female diaconate. ([lifesitenews.com](https://www.lifesitenews.com/news/archbishop-of-algiers-says-catholics-must-abandon-the-idea-that-we-have-to-evangelize/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Dominique Mathieu OFMConv
Background: Cardinal Dominique Joseph Mathieu, O.F.M. Conv., born on June 13, 1963, in Arlon, Belgium, is a Conventual Franciscan who has served as Archbishop of Tehran-Isfahan since 2021 and was elevated to the cardinalate by Pope Francis on December 7, 2024. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_mathieu_j.html?utm_source=openai)) His ministry has been marked by a commitment to interreligious dialogue, particularly with the Islamic world, and a call for global peace through the abandonment of supremacy ambitions. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2024-10/cardinal-elect-matthieu-domination-ambitions-bar-path-to-peace.html?utm_source=openai)) He emphasizes fraternity, reconciliation, and unity, urging concrete actions to build peace and promote justice. ([franciscanvoice.org](https://franciscanvoice.org/cardinal-dominique-mathieu-ofm-conv/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Roberto Repole
Role_Office: Archbishop of Turin and Bishop of Susa
Background: Cardinal Roberto Repole, born in 1967 in Turin, Italy, is a theologian and academic who became Archbishop of Turin and Bishop of Susa in 2022 and was made a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. He is known for his deep scholarship in ecclesiology and his advocacy for synodality, emphasizing the importance of communal discernment, dialogue, and openness within the Catholic Church. Repole has contributed extensively to theological discussions in Italy, backing Pope Francis' reforms and calling for a more inclusive, listening Church that engages with modern challenges while remaining rooted in tradition.

Name: Baldassare Reina
Role_Office: Vicar General for Rome and Archpriest of the Papal Basilica of Saint John Lateran
Background: Cardinal Baldassare Reina, born on November 26, 1970, in San Giovanni Gemini, Italy, has served as Vicar General of the Diocese of Rome since October 2024. Ordained a priest in 1995, he held various roles in the Archdiocese of Agrigento, including rector of the major seminary. Appointed auxiliary bishop of Rome in 2022, he became vicegerent in 2023 and was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis on December 7, 2024. Cardinal Reina advocates for a transparent and humble Church, emphasizing service, humility, and charity in his leadership. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_reina_b.html?utm_source=openai), [ilmessaggero.it](https://www.ilmessaggero.it/en/cardinal_baldassarre_reina_outlines_vision_for_a_transparent_and_humble_church_in_rome-8400378.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Frank Leo
Background: Cardinal Frank Leo, born in Montréal in 1971 to Italian immigrant parents, has had a distinguished career within the Catholic Church. Ordained in 1996, he served in various parish roles before entering the Holy See's diplomatic service, with postings in Australia and Hong Kong. Returning to Canada in 2012, he contributed to seminary education and held leadership positions, including Secretary General of the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops. Appointed Archbishop of Toronto in 2023 and elevated to Cardinal in 2024, Leo emphasizes the Church's outreach beginning "from the human heart," advocating for a spiritual awakening to address contemporary challenges like secularism and political polarization. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2024-12/cardinal-frank-leo-church-outreach-start-from-human-heart.html?utm_source=openai)) He also highlights the importance of pastoral care for families and youth, stressing the need for the Church to listen and guide amidst modern anxieties. ([vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2024-12/cardinal-frank-leo-church-outreach-start-from-human-heart.html?utm_source=openai))

Name: Mykola Bychok CSsR
Role_Office: Eparch of Saints Peter and Paul of Melbourne ( Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church )
Background: Born on February 13, 1980, in Ternopil, Ukraine, Cardinal Mykola Bychok joined the Redemptorist Order in 1997 and was ordained a priest in 2005. He served in Russia, Ukraine, and the United States before being appointed Eparchial Bishop of Saints Peter and Paul of Melbourne in 2020. Elevated to cardinal in December 2024, he emphasizes the Church's role as a mediator for just peace globally and advocates for combating secularization by helping people rediscover the love of God through the sacraments. ([cssr.news](https://www.cssr.news/2024/10/called-to-be-more-servant-than-eminence-an-interview-of-cardinal-elect-mykola-bychok-cssr-given-to-losservatore-romano/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Domenico Battaglia
Background: Cardinal Domenico Battaglia, born on January 20, 1963, in Satriano, Italy, was ordained a priest in 1988 and has dedicated his ministry to serving marginalized communities, including those struggling with addiction, victims of domestic violence, the elderly, and the unemployed. He served as Bishop of Cerreto Sannita-Telese-Sant'Agata de' Goti from 2016 to 2020 and was appointed Archbishop of Naples in 2020. Elevated to cardinal in December 2024, Battaglia views his role as a call to "embrace the cross of the weakest," emphasizing service over honor and advocating for a Church that actively engages with society's peripheries. ([catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/260867/new-cardinal-from-naples-sees-red-hat-as-call-to-embrace-the-cross-of-the-weakest?utm_source=openai)) He has been outspoken against organized crime, particularly the Camorra in Naples, urging members to "be converted" and highlighting the need for faith to be lived out in daily life, beyond the confines of the Church. ([catholicnewsagency.com](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/260475/italys-mafia-fighting-street-priest-archbishop-domenico-battaglia-to-become-a-cardinal?utm_source=openai))

Name: Dominique Mamberti
Role_Office: Prefect of the Supreme Tribunal of the Apostolic Signatura
Background: Cardinal Dominique Mamberti is a French prelate of the Catholic Church, born in Morocco in 1952, known for his distinguished career as a Vatican diplomat and canon lawyer. He served as the Vatican’s Secretary for Relations with States (effectively its Foreign Minister) from 2006 to 2014, where he represented the Holy See at international forums and advocated for religious freedom, peace, and dialogue, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa. Appointed Prefect of the Apostolic Signatura in 2014, Mamberti is considered a moderate conservative, emphasizing the Church’s traditional teachings while advocating respectful engagement with secular institutions and other faiths.

Name: Mario Zenari
Background: Cardinal Mario Zenari is an Italian prelate of the Catholic Church, born in 1946, who has served as the Apostolic Nuncio to Syria since 2008, a role in which he has become a key Vatican diplomat amid the country's ongoing civil war. Elevated to cardinal in 2016 by Pope Francis, Zenari is recognized for his commitment to humanitarian work and dialogue in conflict zones, consistently advocating for peace, support for victims of violence, and the protection of Syria's Christian minority. He has publicly stressed the need for international solidarity with the Syrian people and has often emphasized the Vatican’s impartiality and dedication to humanitarian aid, rather than political interests.

Name: Kevin Farrell
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for the Laity, Family and Life and Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church
Background: Cardinal Kevin Farrell, born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1947, is an influential prelate of the Roman Catholic Church who has served as the Prefect of the Dicastery for the Laity, Family and Life since 2016. Formerly the Bishop of Dallas, Farrell is known for his advocacy of greater lay involvement in the Church, fostering synodality, and addressing contemporary issues affecting families and youth. He is viewed as a pragmatic and pastoral leader, generally supportive of Pope Francis’ reforms and emphasis on mercy, dialogue, and inclusion, especially regarding marginalized groups within the Church. Farrell has also faced scrutiny due to his connections to former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, but has denied prior knowledge of McCarrick’s abuses.

Name: Konrad Krajewski
Background: Cardinal Konrad Krajewski, a Polish prelate born in 1963, serves as the Papal Almoner, responsible for the Pope’s charitable activities. Known for his deep personal commitment to serving the poor and marginalized, Krajewski is often seen engaging directly in acts of charity, such as distributing food and setting up shelters for the homeless. A close confidant of Pope Francis, he embodies the Pope’s vision of a “poor Church for the poor” and advocates practical, hands-on solidarity over bureaucracy. His views emphasize compassion, social justice, and the active presence of the Church among society’s most vulnerable.

Name: José Tolentino de Mendonça
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Culture and Education
Background: Cardinal José Tolentino de Mendonça is a Portuguese theologian, poet, and biblical scholar born in 1965. He was appointed a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019 and currently serves as the Prefect of the Dicastery for Culture and Education in the Vatican. Known for his embrace of dialogue between faith and contemporary culture, de Mendonça emphasizes the importance of listening, inclusion, and the integration of literature and arts into theological reflection. He frequently advocates for a Church that is open, compassionate, and attentive to the margins, aligning closely with the reformist and synodal vision of Pope Francis.

Name: Michael Czerny SJ
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development
Background: Cardinal Michael Czerny SJ is a Canadian Jesuit priest and theologian, born in 1946 in Czechoslovakia before emigrating to Canada. He is known for his work in social justice, migration, refugees, and ecological issues. Appointed a cardinal by Pope Francis in 2019, Czerny serves as Prefect of the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development. He closely aligns with Pope Francis’s vision, advocating for the rights of migrants, environmental stewardship, economic justice, and a Church that is welcoming and inclusive. His views emphasize compassionate action, care for the marginalized, and systemic change rooted in Catholic social teaching.

Name: Mario Grech
Role_Office: Secretary-General of the Synod of Bishops
Background: Cardinal Mario Grech, born in Qala, Malta, in 1957, has been a prominent figure in the Catholic Church, serving as the Secretary General of the Synod of Bishops since 2020. Ordained in 1984, he earned a doctorate in canon law from the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas and served as Bishop of Gozo from 2005 to 2019. Initially perceived as conservative, Grech has become a proponent of Pope Francis' reforms, advocating for a more inclusive Church, particularly towards LGBTQ+ individuals and those in complex family situations. He emphasizes synodality as essential for evangelization, asserting that the Church must engage all members in decision-making processes to remain relevant. Grech also supports the reintroduction of women deacons, reflecting his commitment to expanding roles for women within the Church. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_grech_m.html?utm_source=openai), [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Grech?utm_source=openai), [acireland.ie](https://acireland.ie/synodality-a-must-for-evangelisation-cardinal-mario-grech/?utm_source=openai), [simonmercieca.com](https://simonmercieca.com/2024/07/10/cardinal-mario-grech-is-working-towards-the-re-introduction-of-women-deacons-in-the-catholic-church/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Marcello Semeraro
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for the Causes of Saints
Background: Cardinal Marcello Semeraro, born on December 22, 1947, in Monteroni di Lecce, Italy, is a prominent figure in the Catholic Church, currently serving as the Prefect of the Congregation for the Causes of Saints since October 2020. Ordained a priest in 1971, he earned a Doctorate in Theology from the Pontifical Lateran University. His episcopal career includes roles as Bishop of Oria (1998–2004) and Bishop of Albano (2004–2020). As Secretary of Pope Francis's Council of Cardinals from 2013 to 2020, Semeraro emphasized the Church's missionary role, advocating for reforms that prioritize evangelization over doctrinal rigidity. He supports the legal recognition of same-sex civil unions, provided they are not equated with marriage, and underscores the importance of welcoming LGBT individuals as baptized Christians. Additionally, he views remarriage after divorce positively, interpreting it as a continued faith in the institution of marriage. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcello_Semeraro?utm_source=openai), [cruxnow.com](https://cruxnow.com/vatican/2019/06/curial-aide-says-reform-is-about-mission-not-doctrine?utm_source=openai), [catholicmasses.org](https://catholicmasses.org/pope-francis-appoints-new-members-to-dicastery-for-the-doctrine-of-the-faith/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Mauro Gambetti OFMConv
Role_Office: Vicar General for Vatican City , Archpriest of the Papal Basilica of Saint Peter and President of the Fabric of Saint Peter
Background: Cardinal Mauro Gambetti, OFMConv, is an Italian prelate of the Catholic Church and a member of the Conventual Franciscans. Born in 1965, he served as the Custos (head) of the Sacred Convent of Assisi before being appointed Archpriest of St. Peter’s Basilica in 2021 and made a cardinal by Pope Francis the same year. Known for his pastoral and diplomatic skills, Gambetti emphasizes fraternity, ecological responsibility, and synodality within the Church, reflecting Pope Francis’s priorities. He is seen as a bridge-builder and a spiritual leader focused on dialogue, service to the poor, and fostering a culture of encounter and peace, in line with Franciscan and papal teachings.

Name: Arthur Roche
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments
Background: Cardinal Arthur Roche is an English prelate of the Roman Catholic Church, currently serving as Prefect of the Dicastery for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments, a role he assumed in 2021 after previously holding several positions within the Vatican and the Diocese of Leeds. Known for his deep commitment to liturgical matters, Roche is recognized as a proponent of the reforms of the Second Vatican Council, advocating for the use of vernacular languages in the liturgy while upholding the need for reverence and fidelity to liturgical norms. His tenure has been marked by efforts to implement Pope Francis' directives—most notably *Traditionis custodes*, which restricts the use of the traditional Latin Mass—emphasizing unity in worship and obedience to papal authority.

Name: Lazarus You Heung-sik
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for the Clergy
Background: Cardinal Lazarus You Heung-sik is a South Korean prelate of the Catholic Church who has served as the Prefect of the Dicastery for the Clergy since 2021, making him one of the highest-ranking Asian officials in the Vatican. Born in 1951, he was ordained a priest in 1979 and became Bishop of Daejeon in 2003. Known for his pastoral approach and support of Pope Francis’s reforms, Cardinal You emphasizes dialogue, humility, and service, advocating for a more inclusive and compassionate Church. He is recognized for his commitment to peace and reconciliation, particularly on the Korean peninsula, and for championing transparency and integrity in Church governance.

Name: Claudio Gugerotti
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for the Eastern Churches
Background: Cardinal Claudio Gugerotti, born in Verona, Italy, on October 7, 1955, is a seasoned Vatican diplomat and scholar specializing in Eastern Churches. Ordained in 1982, he holds degrees in Eastern languages and sacred liturgy, and has taught at various universities, including the Pontifical Oriental Institute. His diplomatic career includes serving as Apostolic Nuncio to Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Ukraine, and Great Britain. In November 2022, Pope Francis appointed him Prefect of the Dicastery for the Eastern Churches, and he was created cardinal in September 2023. Gugerotti has been vocal about global conflicts, condemning the war in Ukraine as "barbaric" and a "slaughter," and advocating for Christians to play a leading role in rebuilding Syria. ([cruxnow.com](https://cruxnow.com/2023-consistory-and-synod-for-synodality/2023/10/former-papal-envoy-to-ukraine-calls-war-barbaric-and-a-slaughter?utm_source=openai), [vaticannews.va](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-01/cardinal-gugerotti-papal-envoy-syria-christians-aleppo.html?utm_source=openai)) He emphasizes the Vatican's commitment to open dialogue with all parties, reflecting a diplomacy rooted in "possible utopias" rather than political calculations. ([news.diocesetucson.org](https://news.diocesetucson.org/news/vatican-keeps-doors-of-dialogue-open-to-everyone-new-cardinal-says?utm_source=openai), [aleteia.org](https://aleteia.org/2023/09/30/cardinal-to-be-claudio-gugerotti-expert-in-eastern-europe?utm_source=openai))

Name: Víctor Manuel Fernández
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith
Background: Cardinal Víctor Manuel Fernández is an Argentine theologian and close confidant of Pope Francis, known for his progressive views within the Catholic Church. Appointed Prefect of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith in 2023, he previously served as Rector of the Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina and Archbishop of La Plata. Fernández is recognized for advocating greater pastoral flexibility, openness to marginalized groups, and a more welcoming approach to issues such as communion for divorced and remarried Catholics. He has contributed significantly to papal documents like "Evangelii Gaudium" and "Amoris Laetitia," reflecting his emphasis on mercy, dialogue, and accompaniment over rigid doctrinal enforcement.

Name: Emil Paul Tscherrig
Role_Office: Apostolic Nuncio emeritus to Italy and San Marino
Background: Cardinal Emil Paul Tscherrig, born on February 3, 1947, in Unterems, Switzerland, is a seasoned Vatican diplomat who has served as Apostolic Nuncio in various countries, including Burundi, Argentina, and Italy—the latter being a historic appointment as the first non-Italian in that role. Ordained in 1974 and entering the Holy See's diplomatic service in 1978, he was elevated to cardinal by Pope Francis in 2023. Tscherrig has publicly condemned religious fundamentalism, stating it is "never acceptable" and often exploited to justify extremism or personal failures. ([en.m.wikiquote.org](https://en.m.wikiquote.org/wiki/Emil_Paul_Tscherrig?utm_source=openai))

Name: Christophe Pierre
Role_Office: Apostolic Nuncio to the United States
Background: Cardinal Christophe Pierre is a French prelate and seasoned Vatican diplomat who has served as the Apostolic Nuncio to the United States since 2016. With extensive experience in diplomatic postings across countries like Haiti, Uganda, Mexico, and the Holy See, Pierre is known for his deep commitment to dialogue and pastoral sensitivity. He is regarded as a close ally of Pope Francis and an advocate of the Pope’s vision for a more inclusive, listening, and synodal Church. Pierre emphasizes engagement with contemporary societal issues, pastoral accompaniment, and Church reform, aligning himself with Francis’s priorities of mercy, encounter, and attention to the marginalized.

Name: Ángel Fernández Artime SDB
Role_Office: Pro-Prefect of the Dicastery for Institutes of Consecrated Life and Societies of Apostolic Life
Background: Cardinal Ángel Fernández Artime SDB, born in 1960 in Spain, is a member of the Salesians of Don Bosco and became the Rector Major of the congregation in 2014, the first successor of Don Bosco to be created cardinal. Known for his strong commitment to youth ministry, education, and service to marginalized communities, he emphasizes closeness to the poor, synodality, and the adaptability of the Church to contemporary realities. Fernández Artime promotes a vision of the Church that is joyful, inclusive, and mission-oriented, deeply rooted in Salesian values of accompaniment, optimism, and pastoral care, especially toward young people and those on the peripheries.

Name: Rolandas Makrickas
Role_Office: Coadjutor Archpriest of the Papal Basilica of Saint Mary Major
Background: Rolandas Makrickas, born on January 31, 1972, in Biržai, Lithuania, is a Lithuanian Catholic cardinal who has held various significant roles within the Church. After his ordination in 1996, he served in the Holy See's diplomatic service from 2006 to 2021, with assignments in countries including Bolivia, Georgia, Sweden, the United States, and Gabon. In 2021, Pope Francis appointed him as the extraordinary commissioner to oversee the reorganization of the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore's administration. He was consecrated as an archbishop in 2023 and elevated to cardinal in December 2024. Makrickas emphasizes the importance of integrating the Gospel with local cultures, advocating for evangelization that respects and enriches national traditions and customs. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolandas_Makrickas?utm_source=openai), [itlietuviai.it](https://www.itlietuviai.it/busimas-kardinolas-rolandas-makrickas-popiezius-mus-kviecia-gyventi-paprasta-ir-nuosirdu-gyvenima/?utm_source=openai))

Name: Timothy Radcliffe OP
Role_Office: Master emeritus of the Order of Preachers
Background: Cardinal Timothy Radcliffe OP is a British Dominican friar, theologian, and prominent Catholic leader known for his progressive and inclusive approach to Church issues. Born in 1945, he served as Master of the Dominican Order from 1992 to 2001, and has since become an influential speaker and writer, especially on topics of faith, ethics, and social justice. Radcliffe is recognized for advocating for dialogue and compassion within the Church, supporting LGBTQ+ inclusion, and engaging constructively with contemporary cultural challenges, while remaining committed to the core tenets of Catholic doctrine. In 2023, Pope Francis named him a cardinal, acknowledging his significant contribution to the global Church, particularly in promoting synodality and open discussion.

Name: Fabio Baggio CS
Role_Office: Undersecretary of the Migrants and Refugees Section of the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development
Background: Cardinal Fabio Baggio, C.S., born on January 15, 1965, in Bassano del Grappa, Italy, is a member of the Scalabrinian Missionaries, ordained in 1992. He holds a doctorate in Church History from the Pontifical Gregorian University. His extensive missionary work includes roles as a migration consultant for the Chilean Bishops' Conference and Director of the Buenos Aires Archdiocese’s Department of Migration, where he collaborated closely with then-Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio. Baggio has taught at universities across Europe, Latin America, and Asia, and directed the Scalabrini Migration Center in the Philippines. In 2017, he was appointed Under-Secretary of the Migrants and Refugees Section of the Dicastery for Promoting Integral Human Development, and in 2022, he became its sole Under-Secretary. Elevated to cardinal in December 2024, Baggio is a staunch advocate for migrants and refugees, emphasizing the need for improved legal pathways for migration. He also underscores the link between environmental issues and migration, leading the Vatican's ecological initiative, Borgo Laudato Si', to promote ecological conversion and sustainability. ([press.vatican.va](https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/documentation/cardinali_biografie/cardinali_bio_baggio_f.html?utm_source=openai), [aleteia.org](https://aleteia.org/2024/11/25/fabio-baggio-an-advocate-in-rome-for-migrants-and-ecology?utm_source=openai))

Name: George Koovakad
Role_Office: Prefect of the Dicastery for Interreligious Dialogue ( Syro-Malabar Catholic Church )
Background: Cardinal George Jacob Koovakad, born on August 11, 1973, in Chethipuzha, India, is a prominent figure in the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church. Ordained in 2004, he earned a doctorate in canon law from the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in 2006. His extensive diplomatic service includes assignments in Algeria, South Korea, Iran, Costa Rica, and Venezuela. In 2020, he joined the Vatican's Secretariat of State, later becoming responsible for organizing Pope Francis' international travels. Elevated to cardinal in December 2024, he was appointed Prefect of the Dicastery for Interreligious Dialogue in January 2025. Cardinal Koovakad emphasizes recognizing Jesus in others, serving the marginalized, and environmental stewardship, aligning closely with Pope Francis' focus on human fraternity and care for creation. ([collegeofcardinalsreport.com](https://collegeofcardinalsreport.com/cardinals/cardinal-george-jacob-koovakad/?utm_source=openai))
